intro: Apargia livida, commonly known as the pale moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic compounds and umbellate inflorescences. The plant features slender, hollow stems and finely divided, feather-like leaves that give it a delicate appearance. Its flowers, which open at night, are white and emit a subtle fragrance, attracting nocturnal pollinators. Apargia livida is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
